post.title: The Third Pillar
post.author: abelgaxiola
post.excerpt: I have a problem: when I said in my New Year’s resolution that I was going to improve my soul what I really meant is that I have resolved to become a better person. But how do I, or anyone else for that matter, measure the soul?
post.content:
I have a problem: when I said in my New Year’s resolution that I was going to improve my soul what I really meant is that I have resolved to become a better person. But how do I, or anyone else for that matter, measure the soul? Am I a better person now because I give to charities? Or am I simply doing it to fulfill a requirement that I set for myself, or am I doing it to satisfy my own selfish nature? Am I a better person because I haven’t lost my temper in the past 6 months? Or am I only suppressing my emotions and in the process creating a ticking time bomb that will go off with even greater force in the near future?

What really makes a person a better human being? I think that one way of measuring personal growth is for us to remember our mistakes, learn from our mistakes, and stop committing those same mistakes. I like to think that I have learned from my mistakes, and I know that I’m not committing many of my past mistakes; and wish I would have been able to say that I’m not committing any of my past mistakes. But, one thing I know for sure: I’m not what I want to be, and I’m not what I should be, but I’m sure not what I used to be. Why? Because nothing remains static: especially our personality.

Many times I hear people talk about someone they know and say “he is still the same”, or “he’ll never change”. Nothing could be further from the truth. Nothing is the same – ever. And we are always in a state of change – sometimes for the better, but unfortunately sometimes for the worse.

I like to think that I’m changing for the better….
